feedback.Physical object: Excluded — Zero is a conceptual abstraction, not a tangible or physical object.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — Zero was invented and formalized by humans in multiple historical contexts.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — It has no biological basis or origin.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — It is a symbolic placeholder and not inherently fixed in form or function.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — It has no material or spatial structure.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — It is not inherently perceptible; it must be represented visually or symbolically.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — It is not composed of physical matter.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — Not a passive entity in any material or functional sense.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Zero was created intentionally to solve numeric, positional, and representational problems.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — It does not generate any intrinsic output or effect.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — It is not an agent or system for processing anything.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — It has no state to transform.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — It is accessed through representation or language, not via direct interaction.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Excluded — While it is used in systems (e.g., mathematics), it is not itself modular or systemic.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — It does not act or operate independently.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — It is foundational but not functionally critical in any operational sense.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Zero is a symbolic construct used to represent absence, quantity, and position.
feedback.Communicative: Included — Enables efficient numeric communication, especially in positional systems.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Zero is used in and defined by formal logic systems and arithmetic rules.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — Zero operates at various conceptual levels (e.g., positional value, null quantity).
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — The concept influences mathematical and computational reasoning.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Included — It can be referenced in terms of itself (e.g., 'zero of zero'), and has meta-conceptual uses.
feedback.Temporal: Included — It plays a role in representing time (e.g., zero point, starting state).
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Its meaning varies by domain (e.g., null vs zero vs origin).
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Zero emerged through specific historical and cultural developments (e.g., India, Babylon, Mesoamerica).
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — It is standardized within mathematical systems and formal education.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Zero does not reflect social identity or personal roles.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Excluded — Its use is widespread and standardized, but not governed by legal or institutional regulation.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — It is universally taught and foundational in mathematics.
feedback.Visible: Included — It is rendered in symbols (e.g., 0) across notation systems.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Its interpretation depends on domain and symbolic framework.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Zero is known and used across nearly all cultures and systems.

encoding_notes: This encoding captures the Concept of Zero as an intentional, symbolic, logical abstraction with cultural and pedagogical significance. It is not a functional agent but plays a critical representational role across disciplines. The code correctly places weight in the abstract and social layers, with minimal physical or functional attribution.
